ticket.title: Count on has_many associations doesn't respect the association :limit and :offset options
ticket.original-body:
If I have:
@@@ Ruby Class Post < AR:Base has_many :comments, :limit=> 2 end @@@
And run a _count_ or _size_ in the association, it won't respect the :limit (as well as :offset) options, like _find_ will.
Say we have 3 comments:
@@@ Ruby post.comments.count # => 3 # Sql: # SELECT count(*) AS count_all FROM "comments" WHERE # ("comments".post_id = 271642539)
post.comments.length # => 2 # Sql: # SELECT * AS count_all FROM "comments" WHERE # ("comments".post_id = 271642539) LIMIT 2 @@@
To run the attached test that fails use: rake test_sqlite3 TEST=test/cases/associations/has_many_associations_test.rb
Tested on Edge, 2.1, Sqlite3 and Postgres.
#302 by Ryan Bates describes another discrepancy of count vs. find. Maybe it's time for a refactoring _count_ so it uses the same infrastructure to generate the queries as _find_?
ticket.latest-body:
If I have:
@@@ Ruby Class Post < AR:Base has_many :comments, :limit=> 2 end @@@
And run a _count_ or _size_ in the association, it won't respect the :limit (as well as :offset) options, like _find_ will.
Say we have 3 comments:
@@@ Ruby post.comments.count # => 3 # Sql: # SELECT count(*) AS count_all FROM "comments" WHERE # ("comments".post_id = 271642539)
post.comments.length # => 2 # Sql: # SELECT * AS count_all FROM "comments" WHERE # ("comments".post_id = 271642539) LIMIT 2 @@@
To run the attached test that fails use: rake test_sqlite3 TEST=test/cases/associations/has_many_associations_test.rb
Tested on Edge, 2.1, Sqlite3 and Postgres.
#302 by Ryan Bates describes another discrepancy of count vs. find. Maybe it's time for a refactoring _count_ so it uses the same infrastructure to generate the queries as _find_?
ticket.original-body-html:
If I have: 

Class Post < AR:Base
  has_many :comments, :limit=> 2
end

And run a count or size in the association, it won't respect the :limit (as well as :offset) options, like find will.

Say we have 3 comments: 

post.comments.count # => 3 
# Sql:
# SELECT count(*) AS count_all FROM "comments" WHERE
# ("comments".post_id = 271642539)

post.comments.length  # => 2
# Sql:
# SELECT * AS count_all FROM "comments" WHERE
# ("comments".post_id = 271642539) LIMIT 2

To run the attached test that fails use:

rake test_sqlite3 TEST=test/cases/associations/has_many_associations_test.rb

Tested on Edge, 2.1, Sqlite3 and Postgres.

#302 by Ryan Bates describes another discrepancy of count vs. find. Maybe it's time for a refactoring count so it uses the same infrastructure to generate the queries as find?

If I have:
@@@ Ruby Class Post < AR:Base has_many :comments, :limit=> 2 end @@@
And run a _count_ or _size_ in the association, it won't respect the :limit (as well as :offset) options, like _find_ will.
Say we have 3 comments:
@@@ Ruby post.comments.count # => 3 # Sql: # SELECT count(*) AS count_all FROM "comments" WHERE # ("comments".post_id = 271642539)
post.comments.length # => 2 # Sql: # SELECT * AS count_all FROM "comments" WHERE # ("comments".post_id = 271642539) LIMIT 2 @@@
To run the attached test that fails use: rake test_sqlite3 TEST=test/cases/associations/has_many_associations_test.rb
Tested on Edge, 2.1, Sqlite3 and Postgres.
#302 by Ryan Bates describes another discrepancy of count vs. find. Maybe it's time for a refactoring _count_ so it uses the same infrastructure to generate the queries as _find_?
version.body-html:
If I have: 

Class Post < AR:Base
  has_many :comments, :limit=> 2
end

And run a count or size in the association, it won't respect the :limit (as well as :offset) options, like find will.

Say we have 3 comments: 

post.comments.count # => 3 
# Sql:
# SELECT count(*) AS count_all FROM "comments" WHERE
# ("comments".post_id = 271642539)

post.comments.length  # => 2
# Sql:
# SELECT * AS count_all FROM "comments" WHERE
# ("comments".post_id = 271642539) LIMIT 2

To run the attached test that fails use:

rake test_sqlite3 TEST=test/cases/associations/has_many_associations_test.rb

Tested on Edge, 2.1, Sqlite3 and Postgres.

#302 by Ryan Bates describes another discrepancy of count vs. find. Maybe it's time for a refactoring count so it uses the same infrastructure to generate the queries as find?
version.title: Count on has_many associations doesn't respect the association :limit and :offset options

version.body-html:
Do you have ideas on how calculations should be implemented with limit or offset? You can't just throw them at the end of the SQL because limit/offset in that case would apply to the result of the calculation, not the input of it that the option on has_many would imply.

One approach that I can think of is using a subquery, but it is not at all pretty and I'm not sure if all databases can support it:

SELECT COUNT(*) FROM (SELECT * FROM table LIMIT x OFFSET y) AS z;
version.tag: activerecord bug edge has_many tested tests
version.title: Count on has_many associations doesn't respect the association :limit and :offset options

version.body: The count method could check for scoped :offset and :limit and do [[count_sql - offset, 0].max, limit].min instead of counting rows.
version.body-html: The count method could check for scoped :offset and :limit and do [[count_sql - offset, 0].max, limit].min instead of counting rows.
version.tag: activerecord bug edge has_many tested tests
version.title: Count on has_many associations doesn't respect the association :limit and :offset options

version.body: Implemented as per Jeremy's suggestion, included the test in the patch as it didn't apply cleanly.
version.body-html: Implemented as per Jeremy's suggestion, included the test in the patch as it didn't apply cleanly.
version.tag: activerecord bug edge has_many tested tests
version.title: Count on has_many associations doesn't respect the association :limit and :offset options

(from [367942d93bbb99aa2c2f8dc3900cb7c3f2ba4c65]) Implement count limit/offset support for has_many associations
[#348 state:resolved]
Signed-off-by: Jeremy Kemper <jeremy@bitsweat.net> http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/367942d93bbb99aa2c2f8dc3900cb7c3f2ba4c65

version.body: Today, kids as babyish as Ashcan School or nine name-conscious and trend-alert, puma ducati buying at for solid garments rather than just throwing on what’s pure. Here are just some of the brands and trends your children hungered over 2011. The 80′s Are Back.
